head.title: An Easter Roast, Come All the Way From Canada

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: An Easter Roast, Come All the Way From Canada

block.p: To the French and Canadians it's porcelet: the meat of a pig about 20 months old that has both tender succulence and the richer, meatier flavor of more mature pork. Among the chefs serving it now are John Fraser of Compass and Shea Gallante of Cru. Mr. Gallante serves several different cuts on a plate as part of his $110 tasting menu, right.

To the French and Canadians it's porcelet: the meat of a pig about 20 months old that has both tender succulence and the richer, meatier flavor of more mature pork. Among the chefs serving it now are John Fraser of Compass and Shea Gallante of Cru. Mr. Gallante serves several different cuts on a plate as part of his $110 tasting menu, right.

This pork, raised by Carl Rousseau, a farmer in Quebec province, is also being sold at Ottomanelli & Sons, 285 Bleecker Street (Jones Street). Whole hams (about 12 pounds), or portions of the ham, for a nice Easter Sunday roast, run around $8.99 a pound. Kings Super Markets in New Jersey is selling whole legs, shoulders and loins for $7.99 a pound, and smaller cuts for $9.99 to $13.99 a pound. Most Food Emporiums will have the pork next week; the Bridgemarket store has it starting today, $12.99 a pound for rib chops, $7.99 to $9.99 for other cuts, including shanks, shoulder and legs.
